awd_titl_txt: RUI: What happens when payments stop? Collective resource management under the rise and fall of payment for environmental services
awd_abstract_narration:
Payment for Environmental Services (PES), a voluntary transaction in which a resource user receives payment for providing well-defined conservation activities, has emerged as a prominent policy to support the management and provision of critical environmental services (e.g. forest for watershed protection). In recent years, governmental and non-governmental aid and conservation agencies have increasingly supported PES as a tool for sustainable resource management. Despite the widespread use of PES within the US and internationally, we have limited understanding of its ability to support sustained conservation activities. While some studies have shown payments to be effective at attaining conservation gains over the short-term, few studies have examined whether those conservation behaviors are sustained over longer time periods, particularly if payments stop. 

This research examines the extent to which the PES model prompts conservation behavior and communal resource management arrangements that endure, even when payments stop. In 2009, the Ecuadorian government implemented an internationally recognized payment for conservation program that paid communities and households to conserve their native ecosystems. In 2016, the program unexpectedly lost funding and payments stopped. In 2012-2015 the Principal Investigators gathered socio-economic, institutional, ecological, and behavioral data from a set of Ecuadorian communities in 10 provinces to test how the Ecuadorian payment program changed household land-use behaviors and influenced the development of communal resource management arrangements (NSF #SES-1156271). The study found that, under the PES program, households reduced resource use and created collective management arrangements. The proposed research uses this baseline data and gathers socio-economic, institutional, ecological, and behavioral data from the same communities to assess how loss of payments has impacted household land-use decisions and communal resource management. Household and leader questionnaires, focus groups, biophysical data, and aerial photos are analyzed using quantitative, qualitative and spatial analysis techniques. The research findings provide evidenced-based policy lessons for governments and donors wishing to use PES and similar payment initiatives as a mechanism for sustainable resource management.

por.por_cntn:
This project analyzed the ability of an internationally recognized Payment for Environmental Services (PES) program in Ecuador to foster conservation behaviors and communal resource management arrangements that continued, even when payments stopped. In 2009, the Ecuadorian government implemented a payment for conservation program that paid communities and households to conserve their native ecosystems. After six years in operation, the program lost funds and stopped payments. Although payments resumed in 2017, participants were only partially repaid retroactively, and future payments remained uncertain due to funding instability. This sudden interruption of PES program payments allowed us to test how participants' behaviors changed in response to loss of compensation and programmatic uncertainty.

We gathered survey data combined with observed land-use assessments, focus group discussions and leader interviews to 1) estimate the impact of PES program intervention and subsequent loss on household land-use behavior; 2) understand how households and leaders perceived the economic impacts from payment losses; and 3) explore why household conservation behaviors endured in the context of payment loss and uncertainty. Our quasi-experimental design used a difference-in-difference (DID) modeling approach to compare household land-use behavior, namely grazing, between communities in the program and a set of control communities over ten years; before PES payments, during PES payments, and after the period in which payments stopped and future payments were uncertain (n=871 households).

First, our study found that, counter to expectations, PES households sustained their conservation practices, even with payment loss and continued payment uncertainty. In total between 2008 and 2018, the PES program produced a 20% reduction in the number of households grazing animals as compared to the control. Although the greatest impact on grazing occurred during the initial years of the program, households continued to reduce grazing, even during the period of payment loss. Observed data from land transect assessments and analysis of aerial and satellite images further confirmed the continued conservation of the targeted lands.

Second, we found that the conservation practices were sustained even by households and in communities where loss of payments prevented communities from completing development projects and where households lost an important economic resource. In a survey of community leaders (n=44), almost two-thirds said that the loss of payments meant that their communities were unable to complete planned projects.  Likewise, a third of households said that due to the loss of payments they were unable to pay for basic household necessities (n= 279).

Lastly, our results suggest several conditions that may explain why participants continue to conserve and point to specific ways in which PES and similar incentive-based programs may increase the likelihood of sustained behavioral change. First, program participation and the new land-use restrictions were embedded in communal decision-making processes. Leaders and residents emphasized communal autonomy in deciding whether to participate and in creating the land-use rules. When payments stopped, leaders called on households to continue their conservation practices in deference to their own cultural and ecological values, and out of respect for the conservation rules and contracts they had made and collectively signed. Second, the PES contracts and payments prompted livelihood changes that were not easily undone. In 2018, 41% of households stated that due to participating in the PES program, and subsequent land-use restrictions, they had sold their animals that had been previously grazing on the conservation lands (n=279); it would be costly to purchase new animals to resume grazing, making the restrictions particularly sticky. Finally, the PES program worked to nudge participants toward land-use transitions occurring in the broader region. Participant communities and their respective households often used at least part of the payments to shift to dairy farming and ecotourism; livelihood alternatives that they perceived more sustainable. 

Our findings contribute to practice and theory by demonstrating that incentive-based conservation programs can produce new land-use behaviors that persist in a context of payment loss and uncertainty. Furthermore, our study demonstrates how the relationship between economic incentives, motivation and behavior is multifaceted and may depend on a variety of factors including, but not limited to, the targeted behavior, perceived autonomy and self-efficacy, payment type and size, in addition to the micro-governance conditions within a community and the broader decision-making environment.

With respect to broader impacts, we have shared the results with Ministry of the Environment and discussed how some of the lessons could be used as they work to re-implement the PES program. We have also shared our findings with international and national nonprofit organizations working on incentive-based programs, and via the presentation of land-cover maps and workshops with the communities where we worked.

Our study has also contributed to the professional development of Seattle University undergraduate students and graduate students studying at FLACSO University, Ecuador.
